reviews.author: CKL
reviews.comment_content:
1. Introduction
2. Introduction to conduction
3. One-dimensional, steady-state conduction
4. Transient conduction
5. Introduction to convection
6. External flow
7. Internal flow
8. Free convection
9. Radiation: processes and properties
10. Radiation exchange between surfaces

This course explains three modes of heat transfer: conduction, convection and radiation. Conduction part explains how to find the temperature distribution and rate of heat transfer. Convection part explains how to find rate of heat transfer by calculating convection heat transfer coefficient in different situations. Radiation part explains how to find rate of heat transfer by calculating emissivity and heat transfer between surfaces.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching of the professor is average. Since it is 9am lesson, it is easy to fall asleep.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework: 15%
Midterm: 35%
Final exam: 45%
Attendance: 5%

Statistics:
Homework mean: 92.4/100
Midterm mean: 69.1/100
Final exam mean: 60/100

My scores:
Homework: 81.2/100
Midterm: 61/100
Final exam: 100/100

Final grade: A-

Few personal comments:
I was very desperate after the midterm since I got several marks below mean. The prof encourages us not to give us and encouraged us to study hard for the final exam. She said that if we could show great improvement in the final exam, she would help us a bit in the final grade, maybe 1 sub-grade up. I therefore worked very hard, studyed day and night for this course. Finally I got 100 marks in the final exam, which was 40 marks above mean. After some calculation and prediction, I predict that I am in between A and A-. I expect she would keep her promise and help me a bit to get an A. However, I was quite disappointed after the grade was released.  Finally she broke her promise. Does this story means that if you perform somehow badly in midterm (just few marks below mean), even if you work super hard and have extra-ordinary performance in the final exam, you only deserve an A-. How about the rest of the class? I have heard some cases that they got only few marks below mean, they got C+. Frankly speaking, I am quite disappointed with this course. The prof seems to become a killer this year.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is average. There is a weekly assignment with about 4 long questions. You have to submit the corresponding assignment within 1 week that the chapter has just been finished, so it is a bit rush to get all the concepts and finish the assignment on time.

reviews.author: AE
reviews.title: Better Understanding in Heat Transfer (AE student tries MECH required course)
reviews.comment_content:
Four main parts: Conduction, Convection, Radiation, Multimode Heat Transfer

Fundamental Conduction
Thermal Circuit Analogy + Radial System
Conduction with Heat Generation
Extended Surfaces
Lumped Capacitance
Transient Conduction
Numerical Conduction

Fundamental Convection
External Convection
Internal Convection Thermal Consideration + Energy Balance
Internal Convection Correlation
Natural Convection
Phase Change

Radiation Intensity
Radiation Blackbody and Grey Surface
Environmental Radiation and View Factor
Radiation Exchange

Multimode Heat Transfer

Remarks:
Lots of equation
Require fundamental mathematics and physics knowledge, otherwise, it takes some time for you to understand it.
After that, the content is relatively straightforward.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor just follows the slides, but she also tries to have some interactions, like asking questions or having some video demonstrations. I seldom attend the lessons as they are sometimes boring. I prefer reading notes to save some time. If you, however, don't understand the content, attending lessons may help you.

I never attend tutorial sections so I know nothing about it. They upload TA notes which contain hints for the homework. Thus, I recommend reading their notes if you encounter difficulty when doing homework or studying.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 20%
Class Participation 5% (sudden quiz)
Midterm 35%
Final 40%

In my opinion, working steps are important. Even though your answer is wrong in homework and exam, written steps and equations can contribute to some marks. Thus, writing all you know is also fine as the TA/grading is kind.

For midterm and final, questions are similar to those in homework and lecture notes. I recommend remembering the solving methods. Again, the grading is fine. Make sure you try to write all you know, like equations, correlation, etc. Cheatsheet is allowed in both midterm and final.

My grade:
Homework (8 HWs in total):
mostly 100/100, [mean around 87]
Midterm:
100/100, [mean 72.73, highest 100, lowest 0]
Final:
93/100, [mean 45.1, highest 93, lowest 7]

Overall: A+

Put some effort into understanding the questions in lecture notes, TA notes, sample papers, and your grade will not be bad.
reviews.comment_workload:
Just normal MECH course having assignments, quizzes, midterm, and final
One homework per week.
One quiz (attendance checking) per three weeks (?) Not sure.

As an AE student, this additional course didn't affect my academic path in terms of time and effort. Thus, the workload was not high for me.

reviews.author: ceo
reviews.title: Good course!
reviews.comment_content:
This course deals with heat transfer phenomena including conduction, convection and radiation. The basic knowledge of these 3 processes are taught in high school, and this course gives a deeper treatment of them in a more mathematical way and teaches you how to apply those knowledge in engineering applications. Read other reviews for the details of the course content.

Conduction part is easy, but convection is another world because it requires knowledge from Fluid Mechanics (MECH 2210). Review the content from MECH 2210, or you aren't able to understand even one word from the lectures on convection. Although the radiation part is about Modern Physics, we just need to know the results and use them.

Overall, this is just a computation course, for if you use the correct formula and plug the numbers correctly, you can get the right answer. The concepts are not that difficult if you have a strong foundation on thermodynamics and fluid mechanics. Better review MECH 2310 and 2210 before studying this course!
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor can clearly bring out the concepts we need to know from this course, though she has some Mainland accent. The teaching pace is appropriate for everyone to know what's going on. She would sometimes derive the formulas on the lecture notes using whiteboard or a piece of paper. I highly appreciate this, though the derivation is not required.

I skipped all tutorials as it is at 9 am!
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is lenient. Both midterm and final have mean of about 68 or 69 and sd about 18 or 19.

My results:
Assignments (count the highest 8 marks out of 9)(15%): 97.25/100
Midterm (35%): 100/100
Final(45%): 95/100
Grade: A+

From past experience, the mean is about B or B+, which is typical for MECH courses.
reviews.comment_workload:
9 assignments, 1 midterm, 1 final, quizzes

The assignments are almost released weekly, and in this semester, we also have MECH 3610 giving weekly assignments, so it is tough. I can only find sources for some of the problems as some of them are actually past final or midterm questions set by the professor originally.

If you try to do all of those problems by yourself, you will find this rewarding as the problems of the midterm and final have similar difficulty as the assignments.

Quizzes are only used for checking attendance. Just hand in your name and it will count.

reviews.comment_content: It's essentially applied Physics and focuses on the principles of conduction, convection and radiation. Supposedly, you should have learnt this in earlier Physics classes and it just explores them in more depth. It is much more simpler than MECH 2310 (thermodynamics) and I would say more pratical.
reviews.comment_teaching: If we're only looking at MECH professors, she is already one of the better ones in terms of teaching style and clarity. Much better than most of the professors already.
reviews.comment_grading: If you have a cheat sheet with all the formulas written down, then the grading is quite 'good'. Both exams allow students to bring in cheat sheets and if you can even write down the formulas on the exam paper, you can get a couple of marks.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is quite light, with there being weekly homework and some quizzes. So, I would recommend you attending the class.

reviews.author: Globas
reviews.title: A good course worth to take
reviews.comment_content:
The lecture notes and textbook contain a lot of mathematical deduction of formulas that is useful in the exam, but in general they are unimportant. It is enough just to remember the method how equations, results and tables can be used to solve the problems, as well as setting the correct assumptions.

The mathematics at the beginning may frighten the students, but the applications of concepts are rather easy.

Topic 0: Introduction
- Modes of Heat Transfer
- Review of Thermodynamics
Topic 1: 1-D Steady Conduction **
- Governing equations
- Thermal circuit in Cartesian and Radial Systems
- 1-D Steady Conduction /w energy generation
- Extended Surfaces (Fins)
Topic 2: Transient Conduction **
- Lumped Capacitance Model
- Semi-Infinite Solid
Topic 3: 2-D Conduction: Numerical Method (Optional)
Topic 4: Convection ***
- Internal Convection
- External Convection
- Natural Convection
Topic 5: Phase Change (Optional)
Topic 6: Radiation ***
- Radiation Intensity
- Black and Grey Surfaces, Kirchoff's Law
- Environmental Radiation
- View Factors
- Radiation Exchange Between Surfaces
- Multi-mode Heat Transfer
reviews.comment_teaching: Her teaching in terms of English Proficiency is good relative to many MECH professors. She is patient to the questions raised by students.
